title: Research lakehouse-native columnar encoding for multimodal single-cell data
description:
Context: omicsio converts AnnData/MuData to columnar formats (vortex, parquet). The primary design question is how to optimally represent multimodal count/expression matrices in lakehouse table formats.

Two known approaches to evaluate:
- X-Atlas-Orion list-column format: ~/projects/omicslake-workspace/X-Atlas-Orion
- pqdata COO format: ~/projects/omicslake-workspace/pqdata

Two coupled questions:
1. Lakehouse-native representation compatible with both parquet and vortex, building on X-Atlas-Orion and extending to multimodal data
2. Rehydration to AnnData/MuData with Arrow as in-memory intermediate for out-of-core DuckDB processing

Use cases to evaluate against:
- Transcriptomic data with total RNA
- RNA separated by spliced/unspliced
- RNA separated by spliced/unspliced/ambiguous
- Multimodal with ATAC-seq data (10x multiome format)
- MuData structures with modalities of different dimensions

Downstream consumers whose access patterns constrain the format:
- pyrovelocity: ~/projects/pyrovelocity-workspace/pyrovelocity
- stormi: ~/projects/pyrovelocity-workspace/stormi-review/stormi
- hodosome: ~/projects/hodosome-workspace/hodosome

Reference documents in this repo:
- docs/notes/omicsio/single-cell-data-architecture-for-queries-and-training.md
- docs/notes/omicsio/single-cell-processing-pipeline-binseq-to-count-matrices.md
- docs/notes/omicsio/pqdata-vs-xatlas-orion-schema-comparison.md

Context files:
- packages/omicsio/CLAUDE.md -> ~/projects/sciexp/planning/contexts/omicsio.md

Starting artifact: docs/notes/omicsio/research/columnar-encoding-for-multimodal-single-cell-data.md

First round is reference-based research: survey local repos and docs to map the decision space. Output is a framing document capturing what is known, what remains open, and what experiments would resolve the open questions.

title: Migrate predecessor documentation
close_reason: Completed in 8 commits (3957269..26b57b3) on dat-bootstrap branch

title: Create scilake package skeleton
close_reason: Completed in commits a00ba60..2966f3b on dat-bootstrap branch

title: Survey tool landscape from local repos and documentation
description:
Reference-based first pass across candidate tools for scilake's orchestration and catalog layers.

Tools to evaluate: DuckDB, DuckLake, dlt, SQLMesh, Dagster, Flyte.

Key context:
- Migrated ADRs: docs/notes/scilake/architecture/decisions/ (ingestion, metadata-store, orchestration)
- Architecture overview: docs/notes/scilake/architecture/overview.md
- DuckLake source: ~/projects/lakescope-workspace/ducklake/
- scilake context: packages/scilake/CLAUDE.md -> ~/projects/sciexp/planning/contexts/scilake.md

Near-term constraint: DuckLake does not yet support vortex. Plan is managed directory trees of vortex/parquet files first, DuckLake adoption when vortex support lands.

The migrated ADRs favor Dagster (orchestration) and DuckLake (metadata). Treat these as hypotheses to validate, not commitments.

Consider Dagster local dev overhead and production scaling. Flyte is an alternative. SQLMesh may be sufficient alone for some workflows. dlt may complement or overlap with other tools.

Output: assessment of each tool's capabilities, integration points, and constraints. Identification of which combinations to test experimentally and in what order.

title: Implement DuckDB directory-tree catalog management in scilake
description:
Foundation layer for scilake. Implement managed directory trees of vortex/parquet files with DuckDB as query engine.

This is the base that all other tool integrations build on. DuckLake is deferred until it supports vortex; monitor its roadmap.

Implement directly in packages/scilake/ as production code.

HuggingFace Hub integration: upload files and access via DuckDB httpfs extension using hf:// URIs. HF Hub is git-lfs based and supports any file type.

Vortex is increasingly preferred over parquet for performance. Support both formats.

title: Evaluate dlt integration for data ingestion
description:
Evaluate whether dlt adds value for extract-load into managed directory trees.

Consider dlt standalone and composed with an orchestrator (Dagster/Flyte).

Implement directly in packages/scilake/ as production code. If dlt doesn't prove valuable, remove it.

title: Evaluate SQLMesh for transformation layer
description:
Evaluate SQLMesh for incremental transformations over directory-tree data.

Key questions:
- How does SQLMesh integrate with DuckDB?
- Is SQLMesh sufficient as a standalone orchestration solution?
- Or should it be integrated with Dagster/Flyte?

Implement directly in packages/scilake/ as production code.

title: Evaluate orchestration layer
description:
Evaluate whether a dedicated orchestrator is needed and which one.

Options: Dagster, Flyte, SQLMesh-only (if SQLMesh proves sufficient), or no orchestrator.

This depends on findings from the dlt and SQLMesh evaluations â€” which tools survived and how they compose determines what orchestration needs remain.

Consider: local dev environment overhead, production scaling, integration with tools from prior evaluations.

Implement directly in packages/scilake/ as production code.
